title: How do sickness days vary by job type?
analysis_commentary: The group with the smallest percentage of people taking zero sickness days was direct care; this was 42% in 2015, 3 percentage points lower than the proportion for all job roles. Direct care is however the largest staff group and make up over 50% of the workforce (data not shown). The biggest difference for the direct care group is the percentage of staff taking 'more than 40' sickness days; this was 9% in 2015 compared to 5% for managers, supervisors; 7% for professionals and 5% for other staff. This indicates that job roles which are directly involved in providing care and support, on average take more sickness days than those not directly involved; this was 12.1 days in 2015 compared to 10.5 for all job roles.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Personal Social Services: Staff of Social Services Departments
